text:
Tread carefully :slightly_smiling_face: If someone has a "bad relationship with accountability" what you're describing could put them in a tailspin where their performance in other areas starts dropping.

Consider if this is something that 1. you see impeding this person's long-term career growth 2. would result in this person losing their spot on the team.

If it's #1, more clarity around timelines is unlikely to do the trick and it's high-risk that you'll just completely tank this person's productivity and confidence (<https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01BUIBBZI/ref=dp-kindle-redirect?_encoding=UTF8&btkr=1|recommended reading that should help you think through other approaches>)

If it's #2 then you should be using a Performance Improvement Plan, not OKRs, and you should approach it with an abundance of clarity.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
Hey everyone!

I‚Äôm currently in the middle of setting goals that I‚Äôll need to hit, which ultimately, will give me the green light to change my title from Marketing Manager to Senior Marketing Manager.

The goals we currently have in place are kind of silly and both my manager and I know that (this was our V1 effort of setting them), so I‚Äôm trying to get something more refined that way there is 0 wiggle room when the time comes to say ‚ÄúI did this‚Äù or ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do this‚Äù. I‚Äôm a marketing team of one and doing everything from strategy to tactical stuff‚Ä¶ So from my point of view, the goals we‚Äôre setting I‚Äôm already doing. But maybe I‚Äôm missing something here.

Anyways, if you‚Äôre currently a senior marketing manager at a tech company, I‚Äôd love to chat // if you‚Äôd be willing to share your job description with me that would be super helpful too! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
Hey everyone!

I‚Äôm currently in the middle of setting goals that I‚Äôll need to hit, which ultimately, will give me the green light to change my title from Marketing Manager to Senior Marketing Manager.

The goals we currently have in place are kind of silly and both my manager and I know that (this was our V1 effort of setting them), so I‚Äôm trying to get something more refined that way there is 0 wiggle room when the time comes to say ‚ÄúI did this‚Äù or ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do this‚Äù. I‚Äôm a marketing team of one and doing everything from strategy to tactical stuff‚Ä¶ So from my point of view, the goals we‚Äôre setting I‚Äôm already doing. But maybe I‚Äôm missing something here.

Anyways, if you‚Äôre currently a senior marketing manager at a tech company, I‚Äôd love to chat // if you‚Äôd be willing to share your job description with me that would be super helpful too!

text:
It's tough when you're a marketing team of one. Personally, I think the CEO/ your boss should be setting this rather than you.

But, as you know, I'm in this position too and it's not always the way.

As a marketing unit of one, it's ultimately your responsibility to grow the business (especially when you have no sales team).

Therefore, your target must align with business growth. My current quarter target, for example, is to get to 600 conversions per week by the end of october. To get to this figure, I took our current CVR, applied to our traffic figure, and added something to aim at.

It's not scientific, it's definitely not right, but it *might* help you.

help you.

text:
Yeah! I get that, 100%. We‚Äôre trying to avoid things like‚Ä¶ Hit X number or hire X people from a title-perspective. As a marketing team goal, 100% those metrics are there. But, I think we‚Äôre trying to focus this more on hard/soft skills and depth of knowledge. If that makes sense?

But yeah‚Ä¶ super hard to set :confused: I did a ton of research and I think I‚Äôm already there re: skills and title and my manager things so too‚Ä¶ Just wants one final thing to say‚Ä¶ yup you did this, now you get it. :woman-shrugging::skin-tone-2:

text: So, what's the different between a marketing manager and a sr marketing manager? Strategy, autonomy? I think you need to do one thing so suggest you have these skills. How do you prove this? Complete a course, perhaps?

elements.text: So, what's the different between a marketing manager and a sr marketing manager? Strategy, autonomy? I think you need to do one thing so suggest you have these skills. How do you prove this? Complete a course, perhaps?

text:
Yeah - that‚Äôs a great way to look @ it. When I was comparing a bunch of linkedin profiles/payscale data‚Ä¶ the biggest differences were:
1. Senior -> more leading campaigns overall vs. supporting
2. Manager -> Some leading, some support
3. Senior -> people leader (but mostly when it‚Äôs in big orgs)
4. Manager -> not a requirement for any org size

3. Senior -> people leader (but mostly when it‚Äôs in big orgs)

text: There was a lot of overlap between the two though. These were just the main differences I saw

text: <@U010JU2GTND> Not sure if this would help but a different approach I‚Äôm working through now (Sr Manager > Director) is completing a ‚Äúdevelopment project.‚Äù This is something that my manager (VP Content/Comms) and our VP Acquisition weighed in on as a project that would 1) serve a business need; 2) strengthen or grow some of the skills I need to work on to reach that next level. If you‚Äôre pretty much there already, maybe this could be an approach that integrates with what you‚Äôre doing every day (e.g. leading a campaign instead of supporting a campaign) and be that final stamp of approval for a promo?

elements.text: These could be particularly helpful:

text: <@U010JU2GTND> first marketer/marketing team of one is tough. I‚Äôve done it twice and probably would struggle still if I did it again. IMO I‚Äôd worry less about titles (if they‚Äôre tied to promotions, though, I understand). At that stage I think everything levels up to two main priorities. 1. Help make the business successful, 2. Communicate to your manager and rest of the team how you‚Äôre making the business successful. The nuances of Sr. vs Manger are more relevant to bigger companies with many teams of marketers. If you‚Äôre the only marketer there, all of marketing is your job - no matter what your title is :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
<@URB31QKM4>¬†yeah thanks so much that‚Äôs super helpful!¬†:smile:¬†definitely a better way to go about it. One of my thoughts was to build our q4 plan with a more strategic focus vs. just tactical stuff like I did for Q3! So that just solidifies that thought some more!!¬†:pray:¬†thank you :)

<@U019GGT37J8>¬†I would normally 100% be with you! The difference for pushing for the title though (which I should have probably clarified in the ask!) is that I started off as a content marketing manager a little over a year ago. But, as a result of covid, I became a marketing team of one and my role evolved almost overnight from just content to all things marketing. So, part of it is comp (in the future we‚Äôre on a freeze atm), but also recognition for how far I‚Äôve come in the past 6 months both internally and externally. Everything I do is still revolved around making the business successful/continuing to share insights into marketing wins, updates, etc. But, would just be nice to get recognized for it, which I think is a fair ask :woman-shrugging::skin-tone-2:

text:
I joined my company just over a year ago so it‚Äôs still fresh on my mind. Context: I work as a content marketing director at IBM.

30 Days: Discovery. Immerse myself in the business unit--competitors, challenges, differentiators, leader names. Spend time building rapport with day-to-day team. Explore the entire breadth of content (qual and quant).

60 Days: Keep my head down to work on small projects and demonstrate proficiency. Keep notes on process improvement. Start to build alliances with high performers to learn what makes them exceed department expectations.

90 Days: Propose 1-2 new initiatives or processes based on past three months of experiences. Point out ownable quick wins over the last three months and vision for the next three months.

text: <@U011QQDDSJV> I‚Äôm with <@UJG12DM1V>. Some people simply can‚Äôt be quick, efficient employees--they‚Äôre better suited to slower work environments. I have one addition: in today‚Äôs COVID-19 WFH world, you may want to ask your employee how she‚Äôs coping. There could be caretaking or home life issues impeding her.
